w1HpP9hdPIJu0uvB803zSQ.text: I've been here twice and I've loved it both times. Very nice, low-key atmosphere and delicious comfort food. Lots of noodle and rice dishes and grilled meats and vegetables. I'm a big fan of the chicken katsu kare (deep fried chicken cutlet curry over rice) and hiroshimayaki (Japanese style pancake with noodles.)

Qd7WGY-CqotgTJhkQ2uFTg.text: I was wavering between 3 or 4 stars, but 3 it is because I really didn't have anything I was excited about or seeing myself craving. All the dishes were satisfactory, and no particular complaints for service. This place is not too busy, so for a weekend low-key dinner, I would recommend coming here.  The dishes I've tried a bit like tapas- most dishes were too small for one, so we ended up ordering a bunch:  - Takoyaki: deep-fried here. A little skimpy on the octopus, but OK - Grilled eggplant: loved the miso-BBQ sauce that goes with it, decent portions - Korokke: good vegetarian option! Kinda like a Japanese samosa if you aren't familiar - Hanbaggu steak: a ground meat patty with a special sauce without the bun; OK option - Hiroshimayaki: like the Okonomiyaki except you get a layer of yakisoba noodles  Topped off with a Sapporo.

5ARtdTY4oZfHGhDc1w1AVQ.text: Terrible service and Rude waiter ruined a date night. Definitely on blacklist in the future.   We planned to try this place out and it turned out to be a disaster. Not only that waiter took the wrong order- I ordered Tofu coz it was later night so I was planning to have something light, but it turned out to be pork. He did not apologize at all, and even blamed us for not being clear before we left.   This is probably the ONLY restaurant in Pittsburgh charges PLAIN HOT WATER! What a joke.   Definitely not recommended it especially for a date. It might be a terrible night at end for you due to the poor service.

c8VeYQq114ORK5l2JsFOFg.text: Parking: Street parking.   Initial thoughts:  I read some great Yelp reviews about this place and had thought my craving for okonomiyaki would be satisfied.   Wait time: No wait since we had reservations. I recommend making reservations since the place isn't that big and I've heard that it gets quite busy.   Service: Great service. The waitress was very attentive and made sure our glasses were constantly filled, and asked if we were doing okay.   Appetizers/Small dishes: Takoyaki - it was okay; not crispy enough and a bit too mushy inside. Tori no kara-age (boneless fried chicken) - just okay; still not crispy enough and felt a bit oily. Saba no shioyaki (grilled mackerel with salt) - it was good but the piece was too small for $7. I expected it to be a decent size, but it was smaller than my hand.   Main dish: Okonomiyaki - not crispy enough and the sauce was too salty. I was really expecting the okonomiyaki to be great, but I've had better and this didn't really satisfy my craving. Yaki-Udon with chicken - it was fine, nothing could go wrong with this since it's a simple stir-fry.   Dessert: Green tea cheesecake - it was okay...the flavor was sorta strange since it tasted mostly like matcha powder. Green tea ice cream - yes, perfect!  Cost: Prices were pretty normal for Japanese food.   Ambience: Casual, kid-friendly, group-friendly.   Overall: I was disappointed since I read great reviews. I thought the service was great but the food was a bit disappointing. I enjoyed the green tea ice cream the most.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green tea cheesecake, green tea ice cream
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Takoyaki + boneless fried chicken (tori no kara-age)
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hokkaido style okonomiyaki

zD3Y_zQNw7G3lUUHr-siig.text: A savoury grilled blend of cabbage, flour and bacon topped with bonito flakes, mayo and okonomiyaki sauce. That, my friends is the quintessential okonomiyaki. It's a sure classic in Japanese street food. How Pittsburgh didn't have another okonomiyaki joint before this, I cannot fathom, but Teppanyaki Kyoto makes the classic dish ohhh so sexy.   The restaurant serves a variety of other casual Japanese fare, such as rice bowls and noodle dishes, but who are we kidding, the okonomiyaki is the star dish. We tried the gyudon and it was alright - nothing too special to note. But the okonomiyaki, oh man, it was some hunk of goodness. We trekked far and wide to come to this place (it's hidden in a small neighbourhood quite far away from CMU campus) and were forewarned of the 25 minute wait, but all our worries were washed away when we dined on the okonomiyaki. I've had better for far cheaper in New York, but this is the only okonomiyaki joint in Pittsburgh. My hunger for this fat, succulent dish could no longer wait. And skimp they did not.  They're quite adventurous on their okonomiyaki too. You can opt for the regular or the hiroshimayaki (similar to okonomiyaki, but with yakisoba noodles below and a fried egg on top) and even add extra toppings for additional cost. Not sure if the authentic experience in Japan would be this liberal on the toppings, but hey, I wouldn't mind a cheesy kimchi okonomiyaki.  tl;dr: eat here, the okonomiyaki is so worth it.

-peksFze9Yo7NslmhafwjQ.text: It was a good experience. Friendly waitstaff and good food. If you're not into Japanese decor or food, this is not the place for you.

AQ_Bg5l8l-KQs38pvz50jA.text: This restaurant is tucked away in a small side street but the food here is very authentic and delicious.  They specialize in okonomiyaki but they also serve other classic Japanese dishes and interesting appetizers.    The bacon wrapped mochi is amazing, warm/salty/savory and not too heavy.  Definitely get it.  The takoyaki are little flour balls with seafood filing on the inside, crunchy on the outside but soft and warm on the inside.  We got the scallop/squid/shrimp okonomiyaki which was delicious and appropriately portioned to be shared by several adults.  It comes with a nice pan/spoon utensil to help you chop it up into pieces.  Watching the fish flakes move around in the air is always interesting!  Service was fast and friendly, the servers/owners are actually Japanese.  Price is extremely reasonable, we spent about $50 for 3 people sharing varies appetizers and entrees.  Their menu changes itself seasonally so some of the pictures you see on yelp of food may not actually be served in the restaurant (I was looking for the black sesame ice cream but they weren't serving it when I went)  Drinks: I got a 150ml bottle of unfiltered sake for $6 and it was well worth it.  They also have a variety of sweet sake and Japanese beers.  Con: No sushi or fresh fish here so don't expect to have sashimi.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Smooth unfiltered sake
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beautiful Bonita flakes on okonomoyaki (scallops, squid, shrimp)
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hokkaido okonomiyaki

4RpZqSL0OCPJoj3bMRiO1g.text: Okonomiyaki! I've had a long history of curiosity over this particular dish, ever since reading Ranma 1/2 in elementary school. So yup. Many years later, I finally decide that since I won't get any closer to Japan than Narita airport any time soon, it's time to just go ahead and try it in Pittsburgh, since it looked promising enough...  While I can't comment on authenticity, I did enjoy the 2 my friend and I tried. We did the kyoto mix and the hiroshimayaki, and both were very tasty - the batter kind of reminds me of korean seafood pancake in a way, but made different with the topping and sauces. Their pricing on the menu is a little confusing the way it's written, but meat is an extra $2 - both ours were $12 each, and for the size, it might be a little expensive since they're not quite meals on their own. Plus, the $2 portion of meat was quite meager for an extra charge. But taste wise, yay!  We were most impressed by the takyoyaki though - though I've only ever had mediocre ones that were quite doughy. These were smaller, but had a nice dough:octopus ratio, and the texture was very pleasant - crispy on the outside, soft but not mushy on the inside.   Low points:  We wanted to snack on some onigiri while we waited the listed 25min for our mains, but the rice was plain and not seasoned and $2 each so I would skip these.  Matcha cheesecake had the worst dry texture and didn't taste of green tea at all... or anything besides just cream cheese. Too much cream cheese. We didn't finish our tiny slice. Service was very slow - friendly, but understaffed. The restaurant isn't huge, but it certainly takes more than 1 waiter and one foodrunner to man the whole place, which is what it seemed like was happening. Poor kid.   Enjoyable meal, highs an lows. Good enough for novelty's sake, but I wouldn't return often since it's a bit expensive for what you get. Worth at least a try or two though! A high 3/low 4 stars I guess

GSFGcXg19oH-hc4wknt4Hg.text: Love it there so much. I miss Japanese food and here make me feel satisfied. I'll definitely go back. The waiter is really friendly too.

GIIQbSREElldIynAtWkcnA.text: Stopped by for a quick lunch. The place was doing a very nice lunch business. Service was friendly and attentive. The lunch menu was very nice. I sat at the bar and had the Shoyu Ramen for $11. The ramen was very flavorful and the noodles had a nice bite, not too limp. It was a great lunch for a very cold afternoon. I plan on going back and sampling the rest of the menu, but based on the ramen alone I would highly recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shoyu Ramen. Excellent!

WYfZEUMyLCDiya2XLAeLLQ.text: I went here twice during this past winter. It took me two times to figure out my feelings on this place. I studied in Japan for a year. While I was there, I prized myself as a bit of a foodie. One of my favorites was okonomiyaki, in particular Hiroshimayaki.  Between the two times I went to Teppanyaki Kyoto, I got the Hiroshimayaki and a mixture of their appetizers:  takoyaki, crochets, those rice cakes with bacon and gyoza. The appetizers were fine, but the crochets were frozen and not made from scratch. It seems a bit funny to be paying do much for frozen food ...  Hiroshimayaki is a Hiroshima's take on okonomiyaki. Rather than mixing the ingredients during preparation, the ingredients are layered with soba or udon noodles and then steamed instead of fried. Ideally, Hiroshimayaki is much lighter in taste than its Osaka cousin. Here the Hiroshimayaki was so heavy it made my stomach ache, and the pork was a little too gristly for my tastes.  Overall, it wasn't a bad experience, I just don't think I will go again.

k22PcInfGqW5u-uRE_lRTw.text: I ate here a few Thursdays ago for dinner with my girlfriend.  We had actually tried to go here the Thursday before with a friend but were turned away since the whole restaurant was reserved for a rehearsal dinner.  After entering the restaurant we were asked if we would like to sit at a table or the bar and choose the table while in hindsight I wish that we had chosen the bar.  The reason that I say this is that you could watch the food being made if you sit at the bar while we did not have as good of a view from our seats.  As a whole the restaurant looked nice and clean place and had some good Japanese music playing in the background.  My girlfriend and I decided to start off dinner with the octopus ball appetizer.  It was surprisingly good with the outside of the ball being crunchy while the inside was creamy and contained a surprisingly large piece of octopus.  For our entrees I decided to get order one of their specialties, the Hokkaido Okonomiyaki while my girlfriend had a noodle dish.  On the menu there is a note that the Okonomiyaki take 25 minutes to cook which was not a problem for us.  My entree consisted of a Japanese wheat pancake covered in Japanese mayonnaise, seaweed powder and bonito flakes and stuffed underneath with a bunch of different seafood and cabbage.  Overall I enjoyed the taste of it as it was something that I had never had before.  It looked nice visually with the orange mayonnaise and had a bunch of different textures from the crispy cabbage to the soft pancake and thin bonito flakes.  Even though I did not do it myself I would recommend that you scrape some of the mayo off of the top as there does seem to be quite a bit of it.  My girlfriends dish also had a nice taste to it and I enjoyed it as well.  The bottom line for me is that I would head back here in the future.  The restaurant itself has a nice feel to it, the staff was incredibly pleasant and I really enjoyed getting some good food that I am not sure you can get elsewhere in the city.  It was also much cheaper than expected which both my girlfriend and myself were happy about.

Sam-WVpsf98G0uqoWfRTOA.text: My neighborhood just keeps getting better and better, and I'm grateful that the extremely kind, attentive staff at Teppanyaki Kyoto is part of that. My friend and I really enjoyed our dinner.  We shared some miso fried chicken (tasty!). I had a Hiroshima pancake--one of the more memorable dishes of my life--and she had a more noodley entree. Both were great. I think the prices are fair. I'll be back!

eNMbMf1Q2stmohrRnPwLEQ.text: The Okonomiyaki is great as are the octopus fritters.   Has a great casual feel -- a neighborhood place in Tokyo transported to Highland Park.   The wait staff are a bit uneven in their attentiveness but it only reached the level of amusing rather than annoying.

0s6e9xpX4M51d0qa-yAt6Q.text: I thought Salt was in the East End?!  Spending a lot of time Korea the wife and I definitely like Japanese comfort food.  There is no shortage of trendy Japanese places in Seoul and to mix t up we tried a bunch while living there.  Teppanyaki has to be my favorite type of Japanese fare with the exception of maybe Yakitori.    Ok, now that I've established some prior knowledge I'll review the restaurant.  The place is small and gets pretty noisy, we had a group of 9 including 5 kindergarten age children sitting next to us.  I swear this did not negatively sway my review, but I must say we did not enjoy sitting next to them.  The decor didn't really remind me of Japan and is very minimalistic.  We didn't get any alcohol sadly since the wife is pregnant (yeah considering that prior sentence funny huh).  I got the Oolong iced tea, and was a little miffed that there weren't free refills.  Another miff was that how our food was brought out.  We ordered 2 appetizers, ramen, and okonomiyaki.  The ramen came out first, then one appetizer, then the okonomiyaki, then the other appetizer?!  Very strange and annoying.  Now the food. Miso Ramen with pork - The noodles were good, but not the best I've had, chewy though, so good enough.  The ramen comes with fish cake, scallions, bamboo shoots, and pork.  The pork was really good, the bamboo shoots were very chewy and seemed canned and old.  And now the broth, the most important part of ramen.  It was really salty and didn't have much flavor other than salt.  Sad really, because ramen can be SO incredibly good. Butaniku no shogayaki - Grilled pork with ginger sauce and onions - This was decent, again too much salt, but good.  The pork was lean and no dry.  The onions were sweet and the sauce was full of flavor.  I finished it, but needed a lot of tea and water to do so. Bacon wrapped mochi - This was the show stealer.  I'd go back just to order this.  You get two nice sized chewy rice cakes wrapped in bacon drizzled with soy sauce reduction and sprinkled with nori.  Very good dish, could have just used a little less .....SALT! Okonomiyaki - The Japanese pancake that you kind of have to get if going to a Teppanyaki place.  We got ours with pork, PORK OVERLOAD!!!  It was good, I guess...not sure what else to say other than it was decent minus the salt yet again.  The Bento flakes didn't taste fishy at all which was also disappointing.   I don't think my blood pressure could handle another visit anytime soon, so I think I will just buy Korean rice cakes and make the only dish I really enjoyed myself.

zCHeetpZzQI4EzYyLt0H9A.text: I was so happy when this little place opened up in my neighborhood.  The vegetarian selection is kind of slim but totally tasty.  I never feel weighed down by the food in fact I find this food to be very healing.  The atmosphere is great and I love everything they put on my plate.

SrkdHvRut0YL9pZDFSZQCg.text: I went here a few weeks back with several friends.  One is Japanese and her family owns a restaurant in Japan.  Needless to say, she knows authentic Japanese cuisine so this visit was as much for her to see if this was truly authentic as it was for me to try my first Japanese pancake.  Overall, it was a solid experience,  First, the space seems very traditional and you could tell that the owners focused on the details and put a lot of effort into the design.  You first enter a reception area, then turn right to see the hibachi kitchen with a bar in front on the right and some table and chairs on the left.  As you proceed past this area, you walk up a step to an area in the back of the restaurant that has traditional Japanese seating, i.e. large tables in separate rooms with floor seating.  Overall, the decor and layout is very appealing.  But we didnt come for the decor, we came for the food.  When we first sat down, I glanced to our neighbors plates and everything looked absolutely delicious which gave me a good feeling.  And the smell was overwhelming.  There is no other way to describe it other than fresh.  Regardless of what was on the grille, it just smelled like fresh vegetables.  This too gave me a good feeling.    My wife and I started off with an appetizer and I cant remember what it was but I do remember that it was awesome. Then for our entrees, we ordered the Japanese pancakes (yaki).  They come in two styles - OkonomiYaki which is basically an open faced pancake and HiroshimaYaki which is like a sandwich.  We got one of each - OkonomiYaki in Hokaiddo style which is scallops, shrimp and some other fish and HiroshimaYaki which we got in beef.  They were both delicious.  I have never had anything like this before and it was better than I could have expected.  We followed that up with Onogiri which is a rice ball that is toasted on each side which you then wrap in nori (seaweed) and eat.  It wasn't bad but it was just toasted rice.  I will probably pass on that next time.  Then we finished with mochi for dessert.  We split mango and green tea.  Both were delicious.  After dinner the chef came out to our table and we learned that he is Korean but studied in Japan for several years.  He was very nice and I would defintely recommend to try his restaurant.  Pittsburgh has a fairly diverse selection of eateries but this kind of place was lacking.  Teppanyaki Kyoto is a welcome addtion to the scene.

vEe5K7Hodu1DuOClKkDrmA.text: This place is great. Never crowded, unique cuinine, pleasant wait staff.

GIsE2e_16BLQ-5d0634_gQ.text: Having visited Japan several times, I can say the food at Teppanyaki Kyoto is definitely authentic.  The okonomiyaki (a Japanese-style omelet) was excellent, and easily serves two.    There were several great tapas style dishes too including agedashi tofu (deep-fried tofu in a savory sauce), chicken kara age (tender, fried chicken) and takoyaki (a round dumpling with octopus).  Overall, all of our dishes were great.    Service was incredibly pleasant and attentive!

NsbLr2W3tGj5ZT_8ZuIMNQ.text: When we visit a restaurant, the service and attitude of the staff should be a major part of the restaurant experience.  Even if the food is good, it alone cannot rate the restaurant as good one.  I read reviews of this place and wanted to give a try.  Drove 100 miles to check out the fuss about.  I am a native Japanese and know what the Okonomiyaki is although I am not an Okomoniyaki connoisseur.    I ordered 2 appetizers and 1 entree (Tokyo style Okonomiyaki).  The food was good but not notable.  One of the appetizers was served very late; while the entree was already served.  The timing was terrible and I did not want to eat the delayed appetizer so I asked for to-go.    Here are some notes.  I sat at the counter table, right in front of the teppan plate.  This is where you can see the cooking performance and some interactions with a chef, otherwise, why do they setup a counter table?  When I arrived, there were 2 guests at the counter table and they left shortly after my arrival.  I was the only one who sat the counter and I expected a few words to converse with the owner chef... I was wrong.  His unfriendliness and rude attitude completely ignored my presence.  No greeting, no smile, no comments, no inquiries how the food was.  Seriously.  It was on Sunday night, around 8:30PM.  Do I need to worry about the closing time?  I should not have to bu I got an impression from the chef that he just wanted to get the hell out of there and close.  Instead of asking how the food was, he turned himself around and started using his laptop computer, sitting just behind the kitchen.  Really?  Is it that bad to pay some attentions to what you cooked and served?    Overall, my visit to this restaurant turned out one of the worst experiences.  I could cook Okonomiyaki mix at home instead of driving a long distance.  My expectation was very high but my disappointment was greater.  I would not repeat.  This was my first and the last visit.  BTW, after I posted my disappointment on their FB page, the owner's wife or someone whoever really argued with me that there was nothing wrong with what he did.  Really?  Instead of arguing with the unhappy customer, why don't you remorse and review your attitude and try to improve?  Please don't insult the customer.  Is it because I am a Japanese?  You don't need to treat me like an enemy.  Great job, well done.

ea8YTD2ZOiAOmoNj2MOiGA.text: Really enjoyed my lunch at Teppenyaki Kyoto. The Yaki-udon with Pork was delicious, the seaweed salad perfectly dressed. I had a very nice conversation with the owner as I sat at the teppenyaki bar. I can't wait to bring the rest of the family.

_yQNtBpjLieTmt-6jqnROA.text: Awesome place!! Great food, reasonable price,friendly staffs!! Strongly recommended!!

kfdHx4QhNBJgxIx-KIxTqg.text: my favorite Japanese restaurant in pittsburgh! very authentic.

6ppTnM1olWM0ocSKhZSo-A.text: I thought the food was good.  I tried their roasted duck, gyoza, bacon wrapped mochi, their two styles of the japanese pancakes.  I didn't really care for the bacon-wrapped mochi.  The mochi was too chewing.  Everything else was good.  I don't know the two names of the Japanese pancakes but they were made of cabbage and different toppings.  It had the weird waving/moving topping.  I like the one that had the noodles in it.   One of the Yelp photos listed it as okunomiyaki.  A little weird but worth a try.  We sat at the floor table.  Good experience.  The waiter might have been new.  He didn't seem to know much or could recommend stuff.  But overall, I would try this place again for special occasions.  I don't feel it is a place that you can eat everyday.

cEz6UnSpbPr4EmBPT0opLQ.text: I am going to go ahead and give this place a full four stars, even though I don't like those japanese pancakes that this place is known for. These stars go for the takoyaki, which was as good as the dish in japan and is exceedingly rare on American Japanese menus. The stars also go for the silken Tofu, which was also as good as restaurants in Japan. This place is as authentic as it gets outside of Japan and serves traditional homestyle food. There is no americanization and we even sat on the floor with our shoes off. As it should be. As it should be.

CvnIKmRMPX0DRNCcfAO-Eg.text: Feels like you are walking into Japan.  My fiance and I were pleasantly surprised when we randomly decided to try this place on a Friday night.  We sat right at the kitchen counter and watched as they made our  okonomiyaki.   This is a very traditional Japanese restaurant without the sushi.  The service was great and the chef came right over and talked to us for a few minutes when we were done eating.  If you are looking for a cultural experience and want to try something new, I recommend this place.

DBWAUCin-7Wsm7LG0xHPXw.text: Definitely a unique experience. A different "authentic" style Japanese restaurant? Most dishes will not be seen at other places in Pittsburgh (fried mochi wrapped in bacon). Would recommend to try once for the food, but the service was some of the worst ever.

j6yqzbjOUMwaVBpC0kEeYA.text: I have never written a review before, but just for this restaurant, I will.  For my graduation dinner, I wanted my family to eat something special. Something they wouldn't be able to get living in the Bay Area (which is notoriously good for all kinds of Asian food), and also, not so busy of a place that I wouldn't be able to quietly savor the presence of my family. I'm glad Teppanyaki Kyoto is a new restaurant, because if everyone else knew how good it was, I doubt I'd have been able to get that nice quiet atmosphere!  The restaurant is very clean, and the design reminds me the time when I went to Japan, and stayed at a small bed and breakfast. The plating is very aesthetically pleasing, and typical of the Japanese "minimalistic" feel. I knew I was getting good Japanese food when all the people sitting around me were speaking Japanese.  The food was delicious. I have made Okonomiyaki before, and it did not taste as good as the ones here (not that that is surprising). They taste authentically Japanese ,with the kewpie mayo, okonomiyaki sauce, the seaweed, and fish flakes. I also had the sauteed scallops, which was very good. The bacon wrapped mochi was very hard to share, and very bacon-like (so if you like bacon, this is for you!) since it is very stretchy and chewy like the texture of mochi is. The appetizers, as other reviewers have said, are very small; one person could easily finish them. But when you come here, you expect the authentic Japanese experience, and you pay for quality, not quantity. I also did not leave this place hungry, since okonomiyaki, which starts at 9 to 10 dollars, is like the size of a small pizza at Uno's (but of course, much better tasting).  I talked to the chef, and apparently he's Korean, lived in Taiwan (so he could speak with my parents in Mandarin which was very cool!), but he wanted to learn Japanese cooking so much, that he went to Japan, begged the owner of the restaurant he loved there to let him train in the kitchen without pay, and learned how to cook authentic Japanese food. If you talk to him, which I'm sure he'd be happy to, he'd tell you his story. It sounds like one of those "I worked hard and achieved my dream" kind of stories that make you feel warm and fuzzy inside.  You can tell from talking with him that he cares about the highest standard in everything he does, whether it is preparing the food, choosing the tableware (he took a trip to NY to find the best tableware), the architecture, or how to treat his customers. His shop is clean, and he doesn't hire someone else to cook in his place but instead trains just one person to cook exactly to the same standard he does. He even stops and talks with people too.  Overall, it is a great place to eat. If it was closer to where I lived, and if I wasn't a poor college student, I would be a regular here, and bring all my friends and family here. I know the owner would treat him or her just as well as he treated me and my family, and the food will be fresh and tasty.

MbmZdkCsRHh84IwoEZTn9A.text: The owner of this small Japanese restaurant in Highland Park aims to recreate a Japanese experience in Pittsburgh, specializing in okonomi-yaki and Hiroshima-yaki. Based on my many trips to japan, I would say, in my opinion, that he has succeeded. While I watched my Hiroshima-yaki being cooked in front of me, the cooking smells began to transport me back to Kyoto. After my first bite, the trip was complete. The food is authentic and delicious, the atmosphere is decidedly Japanese, and the staff is very friendly and knowledgeable. I will definitely be returning here.

FvJBS2PE4oFG9LHwM0J6Ew.text: Great! Plenty of options for vegetarians.  Food very fresh and well prepared. Fun to order a lot to share and watch it cooking from the counter. Very pleasant atmosphere.

mCGYNPzYp20n74Vv3pZ9-w.text: I moved to Pittsburgh after having lived in Tokyo for 10 months. This restaurant was definitely legit Japanese. While some of the cooks were not Japanese, the detail put into the food and the methods used made it clear that they were trained by Japanese chefs.  We had some of their skewers, okonomiyaki, gyoza and takoyaki. I really loved the okonomiyaki here but the skewers left a bit to be desired. I didn't like that you couldn't just order the specific skewers you wanted and had to order the mix.  My SO loved this place and we definitely plan on returning here.

8iE49HKkEnVYKy77Ijgoig.text: I can echo what most people have been saying. The space is lovely, with an open kitchen for those who enjoy watching the cooking, and nice staff. The okonomiyaki is good, as are most things I've tried on the menu.  In contrast with other reviewers, I did not find the place particularly pricey. The mains are in the $10-20 range, which seems pretty standard, especially given that it's good (I was expecting worse given the reviews).

5-vbMc86r9lUJstAXX6zMg.text: We came here in the winter for okonomiyaki - and it is legit! The ingredients were very fresh - no soggy okonomiyaki. The cabbage in the pancake provided a nice crunch. They also serve Hiroshima-style okonomiyaka, which we were tempted to get but were feeling too full from the day. Next time.  We arrived a few minutes early for dinner and we saw at least 4 other people get out of their cars the same time as us. Seems like a very popular place.  The interior is a Japanese-style restaurant that is casual and low key.  We will definitely be back the next time we are in Pittsburgh to try more!

R9Wqo_gu3YdwAjL2doTchw.text: What a cool little place in Pittsburgh (that I never knew existed)! Walking past, you would think it was your run of the mill Japanese sushi restaurant. Wrong. In fact, they don't have any sushi on the menu. Based on Yelp reviews as well as our waiter, Teppanyaki Kyoto is known for its Okonomiyaki, which is like a cabbage pancake. Sounds boring on paper but in actuality, it is oh so colorful, bold and flavorful. Although delicious served alone, they also offer many different add-ons ranging from different meats, veggies and seafood.   My husband and I visited on a Friday evening. We made sure to make reservations based on other reviews stating how busy they get. At 6:30 pm, the restaurant was relatively empty but quickly filled up within a matter of minutes upon our arrival. The menu was overwhelming with items we were completely unfamiliar with, but the waiter was extremely helpful and very patient as my husband and I drilled him with our newbie questions. One thing to note, they also have a seasonal menu that changes with each season! Another plus: the menu was incredibly affordable and we could sample many items without breaking the bank.   We ended up ordering Takoyaki (octopus fritters, $7), Daigaku Imo (sugar glazed fried sweet potatoes, $3), Okonomiyaki with pork ($11) and Shogayaki Don (ginger pork rice bowl, $8). We also ordered a large size of the Karatanba sake ($14). We shared everything and it was plenty for the two of us for under $50. My favorite would definitely be the Okonomiyaki for its amazing savory blend of flavors: it was sweet from the cabbage, salty and savory from the Okonomiyaki sauce, lightly creamy from the drizzle of mayo and smoky from the bonita fish flakes. When it came out, we noticed the cool movement of the fish flakes. It looked alive, but trust me, it wasn't. The Takoyaki (octopus fritters) had a very similar taste to the Okonomiyaki since it was topped with the same ingredients but the fritter dough seemed a bit dense. Although good, I probably wouldn't order this again for the sake of trying other items from the menu. The Shogayaki Don (ginger pork rice bowl) was comforting, savory and slightly sweet. And the sweet potatoes were very much like dessert, being sweet themselves and covered in a sugar syrup. Luckily, they came out last for us and was a perfect sweet ending to our meal.  I absolutely cannot wait to come back here and try more items from the menu! I can't speak on the authenticity of their food but I certainly can say that you can't find another place serving this type of Japanese cuisine in Pittsburgh.

aQYsHPqdnIM8kOcTyhGZ6A.text: Love this place. Yakitori is amazing and the prep that goes into all their foods is both authentic but original in flavor profile. Favorites - yakitori, onigiri, karaage. Don't love the pancakes though. Too saucy and "pittsburgher" for my taste.

IvjIYF4ErqcRd9ven3aZAg.text: I got a yakisoba here. The flavor was great, but I wish it was a little less salty. It was still pretty good though. I also ordered a green tea mochi ice cream which was really delicious, and the octopus balls which were amazing. Would come back, but maybe not for yakisoba.

IlKRHoiZZgO3ctnBYJqUUA.text: Teppanyaki Kyoto is a gem located in Highland Park.  When you walk inside you're transported to Japan.  The decor and ambiance here is wonderful and so cozy. The wait staff are all incredibly accommodating and lovely.  The food is spectacular and the prices cant be beat.  When eating in, there is a good selection of Japanese alcoholic beverages including sake (duh), beer (tasty), and whiskey (who knew, right?!).  My go to's are any of the "dons" and the gyoza--so, so tasty! Definitely worth eating in here for the ambiance and drink selection BUT they do offer easy take out if you call the restaurant directly to order. My husband and I were on a huge 'shokugeki no soma' (a wonderful food-themed anime) kick for a while and found ourselves craving authentic Japanese, so we were ordering here a little too frequently.

6RiEKJccCNTrELSeVG9ezg.text: Best Japanese food (beyond sushi) in Pittsburgh. So many options! Their menu is adorable. The takoyaki was to die for. I also got the yakisoba noodles. They were excellent. I want to try everything. Great dessert options. Reasonable prices. Most authentic Japanese around. Why wouldn't you come here!?

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Takoyaki mmm
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Curry yakisoba (winter special) with chicken.

A1NBBklUoxZgjd5-hfRfZA.text: My new favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh! I heard good things about their okonomiyaki and made a trip here for lunch to try it. Sadly  it's only served during dinner time. It wasn't that big of deal, because I had a good feeling about this restaurant the moment I stepped in. You totally forget you're in Pittsburgh! The interior and overall ambience is pretty authentic, which is something I don't usually see in other Japanese restaurants in Pittsburgh.   I got the takoyaki for appetizer and yakisoba. The takoyaki was really good, and made fresh, so they were served steaming hot with little octopus pieces in them. I also really liked the yakisoba! When the portion is huge and I don't end up with leftovers, you know it's good (: My boyfriend got the fried mackerel with rice and liked it too! Not too salty or bland.   Although I didn't get to try their famous okonomiyaki (which was my main intention), I still had a pleasant experience. Will definitely be back very soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yakisoba and takoyaki (back)

d8c_sA_xt_ZLAFcMmTW72g.text: I thought that "affordable", "Japanese", and "good" couldn't go together in Pittsburgh. Luckily, this little place captures all three. We had two dishes, one of which was a pork dish with onions and cabbage in a ginger sauce, good. The second dish was the real standout though: the Okonomiyaki is delicious. We got it with egg and beef. I imagine it'd be tasty even without the supplements, but I'd recommend getting one or two. Okonomiyaki is a wheat pancake with cabbage beneath it and some tasty flavoring on top. There's quite a large portion for the price. This is a real Japanese restaurant, doing Japanese ratios--that means that the Okonomiyaki is more about the cabbage and the pancake than the meat, but it is delicious and filling.  The desserts are yummy too--we had a matcha cheesecake slice and a mochi wrapped inside an oak leaf. The desserts are small but reasonably priced.  The server was a bit hard to get a hold of but friendly and did seem to be working hard. And parking is a nightmare--that's just a Highland Park thing.

rxZ1K5S5G5qPOFer71TMFg.text: This is an awful place to visit if you just want real food. They do not offer any of the typical Japanese food other than street food. Might be good if you just want to waste money of several pieces of karaage.

nUubT_--GlwbRYOq2SIVVA.text: It was the first time to visit this restaurant! Since I am Japanese, I am picky about Japanese restaurant. Today, I can say that this was the best Japanese restaurant in Pittsburgh. All the food was amazing and the service was polite too. I can't wait to go back again!!! Highly recommend to make a reservation since there are a lot of people waiting!!

asZ0W9YdEccylVeJ7mxtcw.text: I will give zero if I can. Take 2 hours and still miss our orders. They don't even know they didn't serve us our dish. Charge 'service fee' even though we don't think any tip would worth it. Not coming anymore and would definitely tell my friends. The most angry dinner ever ever in my life.

T5pJmHKknPj88Iaujossaw.text: I literally could eat here everyday!! It's worth the 40 minute drive, always amazing service and amazing food. Great beer great everything! I honestly don't have not one bad thing to say. Everyone should eat here at least once!!

HvNrtOxrOe2JDVjLQttVyw.text: Excellent and authentic. Friendly waitstaff and cooking crew, a hidden gem in Highland Park.

RNU3w0gPsbSbZQbdXu0Rcw.text: Came here with a few friends and we shared several dishes including the tayoyaki, okonomiyaki, and stir fried udon noodles. I thought the food was pretty good; maybe we ordered too many similar dishes, because after a while everything just started to taste like teriyaki sauce. The service was very friendly! I would come back to give some other dishes a try.

D7UI6hL-v4DtGXq4z5XtgA.text: I don't know if it's the salt on the mackerel or if its the overall atmosphere of this place, but it resonates with home cooking.   Everything tastes very sincere and hearty, and didn't fail to sate my ever growing appetite.   We came for the big pancake teppanyaki kyoto was known for but they didn't make it for lunch. So if you're looking to get that, come during dinner time!   However, there was a silver lining. Their lunch sets were fairly priced and comes with miso soup and salad to go with your main course.   Overall, I'd say teppanyaki kyoto is another hidden gem in Pittsburgh. Pay this place a visit if you're ever in the mood for some japanese home food, you won't regret it!

-LpSul9bWO0dJLZHC9YuGA.text: I love this place! The chefs are Taiwanese but have trained in Japan. Very friendly. Liked mostly everything I've ordered there so far.  Shrimp and Avocado - My favorite thing there. They grill the shrimp and avocado and flavor it with Wasabi Soy sauce. Takoyaki - A little small but tastes like what a takoyaki is supposed to taste like. Okonomyaki Kyoto Mix (Corn, Mochi, Tofu) - made with lots of cabbage with some people may not like but I really like it Japanese Curry with Chicken Cutlet - delicious curry with crispy chicken Yaki Soba - This was okay. A little bit bitter for some reason. Kamo Rosu - Pan-roasted Duck Breast Japanese Cheesecake -  not a big fan of cheesecake in general but this was really light. Had texture more like cake than cheesecake.

Try the Japanese okonomiyaki (pancake), or any of the noodle dishes. They also offer a seasonal menu, too!

AtX-kB4mvdsqyXawbN461g.text: I love the layout of the restaurant and I love the authenticity. There are traditional floor seatings in the back for larger groups and I highly recommend taking advantage of this unique offer for the whole feel. Our waiter was super friendly and helpful in explaining the menu. For someone who is unfamiliar with Japanese cuisines, like myself, the foreign names on the menu could be a little daunting.   For appetizers, we got the "Takoyaki squid balls" ($7), recommended by the waiter. I love that the squid balls were actually filled with chunks of real squid. The order came with 6, drizzled with some teriyaki sauce and sprinkled with fish flakes.   The next item we tried was a noodle dish, "yaki-udon" with beef ($11). The udon had a nice chewy texture and smoked flavor, but it was too ordinary. Tasted like something I could throw together myself.   Next to arrive was the "okonomiyaki pancake" Hokkaido mix with squid, shrimp and scallops ($12). In my opinion, this was the most bang for your buck. They were super generous on the seafood and the portion. It was made fresh and still sizzling as it arrived at our table.   Like every dinning experience, there are hits and there are misses. In honor of spring, we decided to give the seasonal menu a try with the scallops and shrimps "hoiru-yaki" ($12, seasonal). The description called for a creamy basil sauce, but what we got was a bland and watery liquid mixed with basil. The presentation lacked sophistication in that thrown-together, crumbled-up foil tray. The whole dish was just bleh. I would never order this again in the future.   For dessert we inhaled the green tea mochi ($2), which melted away all my sorrows, and the lychee sherbet ($3), which was packed with flavors.   Despite the misses, my dinning experience here was phenomenal. For those seeking a more authentic dinning experience at very reasonable prices, I highly recommend giving Teppanyaki a chance. The service was top notch and the food was quality. If you are a noob to Japanese food like myself and is overwhelmed with the menu, I narrowed down my favorites: the "takoyaki" squid balls, "okonomiyaki" pancakes and the green tea mochi.

AQnLllmgnpbiNgd0-kjfEg.text: Truly authentic Japanese restaurant, forget about sushi and hibachi, this is old grandma food. Excellent quality and ambiance

4czdRQtB3mnTMw8L9wJ46Q.text: It's funny how some of the menu items here I'd never had previously, but in the past few years have become absolute comfort food to me.  I live a few blocks and make it here regularly, especially in the winter.   The atmosphere is very Japanese, even the menu has the bright ,fun vibe to it. For such a small place there's lots of different seating options, from more private, to floor seating, to my favorite of sitting right by the griddle.   I love duck, and the kamo-rosu really lets it shine. The takoyaki almost always makes it to our table. The real reason to head here, though, the the okonomiyaki and hiroshimayaki. I've had it other places since, but this is still my go-to.   The staff is always friendly and efficient, and watching them cook is a real treat.

1VJgA5WF7_wr8jKPbT8-pg.text: Good environment. Very classic. Traditional Japanese place. Okonomiyaki is my favorite. EEL is also good. A little pricey if you order alcohol.

nmyoUMybJ3k13p1fTs9BJw.text: Came here just for the okonomiyaki.  It was delish, but they do warn you it takes a while to cook (20 min, I think).  Get a seat in front of the kitchen and watch them make them all!  I was amazed at how the cook managed to keep all of okonomiyaki orders straight even though they were all on one grill.  Service was really good.  Parking can be kind of a pain (street parking).

GBqlkpVoFztNqcqqj1D6oQ.text: This is probably the worst Japanese restaurant in Pittsburgh - I've never ever seen a receptionist with attitude. Never in my life have I ever heard "You know we are busy on weekends, if you wanna come, you should call before" while the restaurant never said it did not accept walk-in customers. When we asked how long we needed to wait, he even said "if you trust me, 20 minutes. If not, please go." I can hardly believe how this restaurant could survive. If you don't wanna be treated like this, definitely don't go.

-jwJPkJ2giPw_Z0BNyVz5g.text: This place is incredible, we went for the first time last night. Great food and friendly staff!!!

zIm2aQ7z_UC7JN6FbXWt8w.text: When I first visited Teppanyaki Kyoto, my knowledge of Japanese food ended at the back page of most menus, the type that feature pretty rolls with cheeky names like "Lady Dynamite Roll" or "Raging Dragon Roll."  This is NOT that Japanese restaurant, and that's a wonderful thing. You will find items you recognize--kara-age (the best, here), takoyaki (also the best I've ever had)--but the real highlight are their seasonal menus and their namesake, the teppanyaki, front and center in the restaurant. On this visit, we shared Kara-age and takoyaki, as well as two seasonal dishes for summer 2018:  bang-bang chicken (a cold dish, reminiscent of a chicken salad, on a bed of quick-pickled, thinly sliced onions) and hiyashi ramen (a cold ramen soup with pork, matchstick vegetables, egg and tomatoes).  All of their food is cooked to perfection. Their service is fast and thorough. If you are new to this type of Japanese food, your server can direct you, based on preferences and comfort level. And, you need to try the signature dishes:  okonomiyaki and hiroshimayaki. These hearty dishes (only during dinner service), layer protein of your choice, cabbage and other fillings in a thin batter. Noodles are a regional addition, in the case of hiroshimayaki Pancake-like, they cone topped with rich sauces and bonito.

O9nIMtEdJkSTP5bqtM1vAg.text: The best izakaya-style Japanese restaurant in Pittsburgh.  One of their specialties is the okonomiyaki.  I can't say it compares to the best I've had elsewhere, but I'm glad it exists in Pittsburgh!

IGPhhIGYj4yqK5wP3QSQgA.text: Definitely want to make a reservation for this place - we made one the day prior and had a bit of an issue where the name was misheard. Luckily, we managed to get seated after the staff decided that it was most likely just some miscommunication.  We enjoyed everything we ordered, from the takoyaki (smooth and chewy), yakitori (the mushrooms on these were superb), grilled eel (quite perfect) and finally the okonomiyaki, which was also good though possibly not my type of dish. The green tea is served from tea bags from Japan and tasted alright, and the mocha ice cream dessert was quite good. Also had a taste of the peach wine, which was smooth, sweet, refreshing, and went down nicely.  Efficient and solid service!

K0CW713qtoMNmVu92t7eIw.text: decently priced grilled small plates in lovely atmosphere.  Fun to go as a group and share food in the back sitting on floor cushions.

i9eFegNgdcZwQCxpq3Vuhw.text: Lived in Hiroshima for a number of years and I've missed the okonomiyaki. This place is amazing. Taste is authentic! This place is a must go.

eryzfVGOEHfcolTM6tn4gQ.text: Five stars to the staff, so friendly, funny and fast. The food and atmosphere is fantastic. Must try.

xJoNJY6E31JIXhqly1o6DQ.text: This place is a True authentic experience. Ginger Pork with rice or Fried Chicken with curry are hands down the best two dishes. Returning for a second time.

HlkGD3XIYlGiatvgfPjekQ.text: By Pittsburgh standards, the food is good. However, I think they are really lacking dinner options. They only have okonomoyaki, two rice dons, and stir fried noodles as entrees. I ordered many appetizers with one entree, and it was pretty expensive for not being too full. But, if you're craving the okonomayaki or takoyaki, I think it's worth coming since there's no other place that does it right!

4oZp8OEqQdt_HF_OSaEqSw.text: This place for sure just found a place on my top 10 favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh. The food is amazing here. Although I caution you that some of the portions are a little small. But, its definitely worth it.   I went there with a group of friends and three of us shared food. Something we do often to give ourselves the chance to try multiple foods from the restaurants we visit. Here, after looking at multiple reviews we decided to go with the following:  1. Seaweed Salad for appetizer. The taste was very good. It was salty with a nice soy like salad dressing. If you don't like slimy food then you might not love it. Otherwise, I think its definitely a must try. Its different if you didn't have seaweed before.  For main dishes we got:  2. Tapoyaki, a small dish of Octopus balls. The best taste and most delicious. It was a fantastic blend of octopus meat and other ingredients. It is a must try in my opinion. The potion is a little small so make sure this is not the only thing you are ordering if you are too hungry.   3. We tried the Okonomyaki which Teppanyaki Kyoti is actually famous for. It was definitely a very tasty. Its a pancake style food with mix of cooked veggies, pancakes and meat. You have many options for toppings for extra. We tried it with shrimp and oyster and it was a great mix. I would for sure suggest it.  4. The last meal of ours was Chicken Katsu Kare. It was a nice Kare but it wasn't anything different or new. It was a fairly simple Kare and very similar to indian food. The taste was nice and good but I felt there more exciting meals to try. However, I should say the portion was really good.   For desert we got the cheese cake and the Kushi-Dango. Both were great but I personally loved the Kushi Dango. Not too sweet but yet very tasty.   I definitely would suggest this restaurant and visit here more often.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Kt0GofEiB_a0T4VrMiPhGA.text: My husband and I have been wanting to check out Teppanyaki Kyoto for awhile now, since we discovered it while we were dining across the street at Park Bruges. We were reminiscing about our trip to Japan last year and wanted to have some okonomiyaki to ease our nostalgia.   As we stepped into the restaurant, it was as if we were being transported to Japan. The ambiance, smells, music, everything made us feel like we have left Pittsburgh entirely. We were seated in the back of the restaurant, in a little private section, which we really didn't mind, though the hostess did give us the option to sit wherever we wanted as we were tempted by the seats on the floor in the tatami room for a few seconds.   For food, we ordered a plate of takoyaki to start. We didn't take long to place our order for our main course as we were starving and on the menu, it stated that it would take 25 minutes to prepare the okonomiyaki. The takoyaki was served very quickly and it tasted pretty good, very close to what we had in Japan.    ~25 minutes later, my hokkaido mix (shrimp, scallop and squid) okonomiyaki and my husband's beef hiroshimayaki arrived. The difference between the okonomiyaki and hiroshimayaki is that the hiroshimayaki has soba noodles in it and  a fried egg on top. The 2 pancakes looked delicious and were surprisingly large and filling. I was a little disappointed in my okonomiyaki because I realized it was thick, because it was packed with cabbage. My seafood okonomiyaki, had 1 shrimp, 2 nscallops, and maybe 3 slices of squid. For the price, I can't complain, and it was still tasty nonetheless.   Our waiter was also very attentive and kept checking on us to make sure our glasses were always filled.  Overall, it was a nice dining experience.

Yp3muRRISke2nAwa7xLCCQ.text: I come here for the okonomiyaki, with the yakitori or other appetizers. The noodles are good, but not special.   The food is not heavy; don't expect to leave feeling 100% full.

XGn7SYifRu7OBqBnk5EkAA.text: Still going strong. What I love about this place is that they strive to keep the classic favorites very consistent, while also maintaining an awesome seasonal menu. I've always loved the "izakaya" tradition, and this place brings it on - strong.  We were here a few weeks ago, and I was delighted to see the one thing that I thought had been missing from their menu: a yakitori sampler plate. We ordered one for our table, and were not disappointed. I would absolutely love it if they would expand this offering with a classic robata binchotan grill along the bar eating area, and serve an even more diverse selection of tasty skewers.  Our favorites here are still the takoyaki, the okonomiyaki, and an amazing dish called "butaniku no shogayaki" which is tasty thin slices of pork and onions with a light teriyaki/garlic sauce. It's awesome. That being said, we have never had anything here that was short of delicious. Another great part of the menu are the Japanese beers and a large selection of sake, anything you could possibly want! We'll keep coming back!!!

CUIwdpsshk2jGT756Ol0yQ.text: There are a few good Japanese restaurants in PIT but Kyoto is one of the best and we make it one of our Go To places every time we are in PIT.  Kevin the owner is a gracious host, always friendly and always quick with a smile.  He and his team of young chefs will from time to time change things up a bit.  This is nice because some restaurants we know will keep the same menu for years.  What we love about Kyoto is that all the dishes are freshly made, not too salty, everything just right.  The service is friendly and fast.  Everything is clean and professional, open kitchen gives me a good feeling for cleanliness.  The place is popular and does get crowded so... keep that in mind.  Nevertheless, even when you have to wait, it is worth it!

5eCmurGiKScCmrzyWm7n-A.text: I think it's funny when the hostess and servers greeted me by saying "MOSHI MOSHI!!".. Only because the phrase is used when answering the telephone and not a greeting you would say in person. Maybe I am wrong?  I love how quaint this restaurant is and the fact that they don't serve sushi is awesome. It's not your typical Japanese restaurant.  They're actually known for their okonomiyaki. I remember the first time I came here and ordered the okonomiyaki, I freaked out because the bonito flakes were moving! I seriously was like, what the hell is that? And the waitress assured me that it wasn't alive and that the flakes are so thin that when exposed to heat or steam it moves around. *whew*  My husband and I split the okonomiyaki (Hiroshima style) with shrimp and ordered the dashi maki, soba, takoyaki, and the yaki onigiri.  Would love to come back to try other dishes and sit by the hibachi! Try their Japanese beer! It's refresshing! Kanpai!!

ITngBPNhtsmWKwKsgCxLKA.text: This is hands down, the best and most authentic Japanese restaurant in Pittsburgh.  I brought a friend who lived in Japan for several years, and he was speechless during the entire meal. We sat at the bar section, and we watched the chef's craft amazing dishes for everyone that was there. Sit at the bar, and enjoy the show and take in those wonderful smells coming from the griddle.  The okonomiyaki tastes like what you'll get in the finest shops in Japan. The korokke was nicely fried, and the takoyaki was scrumptious. For dessert we got the macha cheesecake, and typically I steer away from macha anything. But the flavor was subtle, and it was the perfect dessert for such a wonderful meal.  The service was outstanding, and if you're craving real authentic Japanese food (outside of sushi and ramen), this is the spot to go to. I can't wait to come back and try the yakitori, the yaki-soba, and the hanbaagu steak.

NivKCxZIRyWd55-016seeg.text: There are lots of regulars that love this place, and with good reason. It's a very welcoming Japanese restaurant with authentic cuisine.   Although they are called Kyoto, the restaurant features foods from other regions of Japan, especially the Okonomiyaki pancakes from the city of Hiroshima. So while the owner is from Kyoto, her husband was trained to cook Okonomiyaki.   There's a wide range of Sake, Beer and Shochu, oddly there is no Shochu made from sweet potatoes, which is fairly common in Japan.   The Sakura Mochi was a delectable finish to a wonderful meal. The sweet rice cakes filled with a delicious bean paste quite hit the spot.

rMeGZvUvfHcyA5K64upZSg.text: Low-key, cheap, but interesting Japanese food. Located right in the middle of a small set of restaurants very close to Highland Park. Family friendly kind of place. Small space inside makes for a pretty intimate feel. We sat at a table with some bamboo overhead, which was kind of fun and well-themed. Very friendly service!  My fiance and I got the famous pancake that the restaurant is known for - Okonomiyaki. It's a mix of cabbage, noodle, egg, whatever meats you add (for $1-3 dollars each), and is topped with fish flakes. Very good flavor and an interesting dish! Haven't ever had this kind of thing before, which made it fun. The base pancake with no add-ins is just $11.  We also got a chicken katsu plate (I am surely spelling it wrong). This was more or less chicken and gravy, but with Asian-style, curry-flavored gravy, on a large bed of white rice. So very basic on one hand, but on the other hand kind of an interesting take on chicken and gravy. Pretty filling, only $13.  They have 12oz bottles of Sapporo for just $5.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken Katsu (basically Japanese chicken and gravy)
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Okonomiyaki Pancake

Q1294YoVqwrhM_hlkMgqCw.text: This is an overdue review but we came here for my boytoy's birthday celebration with his friends! We got the tatami floor room towards the back of the restaurant and sat on the floor with cushions. That didn't phase me at all honestly, I'm used to it.  The waiter was super super nice and he made sure that we were all taken care of. We ordered a bunch of small plates here and there to share with everyone. The takoyaki was so super delicious but they were all really good. As an entree we got the chicken katsu kare and I have to say, it was really mediocre. I guess you can't really do anything fancy to the dish, but it was the same as what I could make at home.  We also got a pork okonomiyaki and that was really good. Too much cabbage but it was cooked well and hot.  I think the best part was the matcha cheesecake. Unfortunately they didn't have enough for the entire party because they only make a set amount each day, but that was fine because not everyone wanted a slice anyways. But it was so so good. They also bring out ice cream with a candle for birthdays.  It was a lot of fun and the experience and atmosphere was unlike a lot of restaurants here in Pittsburgh. Though the food wasn't WOWOWOWOW, I don't regret choosing this place for his birthday.

10elFdlf0lQW2rTmKBlb6A.text: I love this place! The first time I came here, I had the Okonomiyaki, which is quite unique and very delicious. I was very excited to return with an out-of-town guest  However, as we were ordering our server informed us that the Okonomiyaki use a fish sauce, which is a no-go for my very strictly vegetarian guest. Credit to our server for telling us this  I was pretty disappointed that my guest couldn't have their speciality, but we ended up ordering several other dishes that were quite good: soba noodles with tofu and kimchi, grilled eggplant, agedashi tofu. My favorite was the soba. For dessert, they were out of mochi, so we settled for the lychee sorbet, which was better than expected  This place does have plenty of good options for vegetarians but unfortunately the "Japanese pancakes" are not one of them.

Vbqe5B2N0z2CLUiIYATddw.text: OVERALL: great Japanese place famous for their okonomiyaki (type of Japanese grilled pancake). Be prepared to wait if you order okonomiyaki because it takes a while to make, especially with a large group. Traditional setting with comfortable seating. A tad pricey, but makes sense.  At Teppanyaki Kyoto, the food is very authentic and the okonomiyaki was definitely an experience. As someone trying it for the first time, I thought it had an interesting flavor, but I liked it, and would be down to try other versions of it. The wait was long (about 40 mins), but it makes sense because of my group of 6 people. I also tried the karaage (Japanese fried chicken) appetizer, which was delicious, but portion size was a bit small.  I would recommend this place to anyone who likes Japanese food, because it's one of the best places I've found in Pittsburgh so far. Also, you have to try the okonomiyaki - it's quite unique, and I haven't found any other place here that makes it.

dLgYB6Db_Cuf50fhkUXQKg.text: This restaurant is phenomenal! We ordered 3 appetizers: the scallops (literally so good I wanted to cry), gyozas, and kimchi pork as well as our own orders of yaki-soba noodles. All the dishes come in small, shareable sizes and it was nice to be able to order so many different things to really get a feel for the place. We sat at the bar which was fun because we got to watch the chefs cook, everything being made looked amazing. Plus the employees were are very nice and attentive. I think this will be one of our regular stops now.

ji_JV9DRy0rZ2RQ0NtvICA.text: Best Japanese food I have had since I've been in japan! Wish I live in Pittsburgh so that I can be a regular at this gem! Great service very friendly waiters and chefs! I will be back when I come back to Pittsburg!

A10vYTGOHEDRVF_FwfDOrQ.text: One of the best authentic Japanese restaurants in Pittsburgh!  I just recently moved to Pittsburgh from Orange County, California. It's been hard finding authentic Japanese food, until I found this restaurant. You get the most legitimate type of izakaya Japanese food on the menu, ranging from yakitori, dashi-maki, takoyaki, yaki soba, etc. The portion size is a little small, depending on what you get, but its expected when you're dining in at a izakaya-style restaurant. Depending on what you get, the food takes some time as well, but worth it.  The employees are lively, greeting you in Japanese, and they make great recommendations when it comes to the food and drink.  The different type of Japanese drinks they have is pretty impressive. They have an extensive alcohol list, with different types of Japanese sake, beer, and whiskey. They even Hibiki whiskey, which is awesome.  Its not the best tasting izakaya food I've ever had, but when you don't have a lot of authentic food option, its the best option you'll get in Pittsburgh.

vlbdspemdAHIgVrNrX_wdw.text: Really enjoyed our gyoza, shrimp yaki  udon, yaki soba with chicken , and Hiroshimiyaki with scallops. My only complaint is the sparse amount of meat in each dish - perhaps 2 bites worth for an additional $3. Still will definitely return. Just won't shell out the extra for the meat.

FIgMAwyKVjFCvk2LButcGA.text: My overall rating is 3 out of 5.  Service was great but food was okay. It is nice to have teppanyaki open kitchen view.  It was interesting to watch chefs using torch.  They also had variety types of japanese alcohol.  But food was quite disappointing as my expectation was high.  Yaki udon was okay.. I tasted too much sesame oil.  Takoyaki was not hot enough..

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

JlXcodTHnZse7SN8R5Ja-w.text: There is something magical about this spot. It feels as if walking through the door way transports you to a small grill in Japan. Humble and clean decor with a super friendly staff. Teppanyaki is like hibachi in a way (metal cook top) but much more regionally specific. I would recommend sitting at the bar in front of the grill if possible.   The menu is probably not what you are familiar with however it clearly explains what every dish is, and is also very seasonally specific with lots of pictures. All of the appetizers are very approachable and shareable which I would recommend. Entrees have a very home cooked feel and fill you up! They provide chop sticks but don't feel shy about asking for a fork if you're not adept with chop sticks.   At its core this is comfort food and you will leave full and happy!

1w1bxG1YYRADztwp6JQePA.text: This restaurant gives off the vibes of an authentic Japanese restaurant, and it delivered on many aspects. Overall, the food can be pricey but sure is tasty!   What I've eaten: -takoyaki is made incredibly well. Crispy on the outside, fluffy inside. They could certainly use more octopus. Sauces that go on top are well-balanced and pair well with takoyaki. - Salt-grilled mackerel is probably my favorite. It's seasoned so well, is always mouth-watering, I always have to share half (all) of it with my dates (I get the bones...) - yakisoba is sweet and savory. Noodles are cooked well, but overall I think the flavor is a bit generic i.e. nothing special. To me this is more of a comfort food  Things I liked: -Everything above about food is great -They have an open kitchen so it's fun watching them cook their dishes  Things I didn't like: -can be pricey for portion sizes, but whatever it's Japanese in mid-west.

VZXXL5nMagPXRf5wlT7uWQ.text: I am not surprised that this place existed in Pitts.  Food is good.  An excellent choice for Japanese food

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

puw9UXe517UM0SpvwGXk6g.text: This is the closest thing to eating at a Japanese izakaya in Pittsburgh. The okonomiyaki is great and similar to my experience in Hiroshima. The other items are great as well. I particularly like takoyaki and dashimaki. I love coming here.

NR-XjquVN56kq6gpEZVBKQ.text: Don't get me wrong, the food was great! But the service was lacking.   My friends and I went at around 8:30 pm for our reservation and were seated promptly. For our party of 7, the waitress only gave us 3 menus and no water. We had to keep flagging her or any other worker down to remind them to bring us more and also glasses of water. It seemed like she was the only waitress on the floor; she could use a little help! We had to keep calling servers over to take our order, as none seemed to approach us.  Tip: order the okonomiyaki first. It takes 25 min to make, but it's worth it! Also, the Hiroshimayaki is another dish that takes a while to make, but it tasted pretty similar to the okonomiyaki so just pick one!  The wait time for the food was not bad as the servers brought out the dishes when they were ready. The portion sizes and flavor were impressive. I'm pleasantly surprised to have found a decent Japanese restaurant in Pittsburgh! The prices weren't too bad either, although one cup of green tea was $2, so I'd be wary of that.   Other than the experience with the servers, everything was up to par. I would come back for the food, maybe order through grubhub or postmates, but maybe not so much for the service.
