Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Either okonomiyaki or hiroshimayaki

BvhqALld_HLDcxywTu4xPw.text: Finally found a decent Japanese Ramen place in Pittsburgh! This restaurant is pretty authentic with solid okonomiyaki (japanese pancake) and takoyaki balls also!   It's a bit pricey and some dishes like the okonomiyaki take pretty long to come out. Expect dishes to come out at different times when you order a large variety - which is kinda annoying especially when you go to eat with friends.   The food overall is pretty good and they have a lunch special that is a bit cheaper but not necessarily "better" in flavor/quality.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken Katsu Kare (Curry)
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yaki Soba
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Miso Katsu

X0L4cvu5UWg0_MHGg0K52Q.text: I was really excited to come here, especially with all the good reviews I read and what pictures I saw. However, I had anything but a satisfying experience at Teppanyaki Kyoto.   I ordered a pretty complete set from the menu: (sorry I forgot most of the Japanese names) - Fried potato cakes: mushy inside, which I guess is intentional but it didn't hold up well, and the texture was just too loose to taste anything. Also, the potato paste inside was too thin, and the breading on the outside didn't hold up very well. 1.5/5 - Octopus balls: Main reason to come here for me. The presentation was great, but the flavor was too salty and I felt that where the food could be savory it was somehow suppressed. Still, good amount of octopus. Didn't really like the filling though, for the same reason as the fried potato cake filling: too thin. 3/5. - Yakisoba: Presentation was not that great, because colors were really dulled and nothing was shiny. Flavor honestly was actually okay, but the chicken tasted like buffet quality, and veggies felt kinda forced---they were too soggy and contrasted with the slightly harder and dry noodles. 3/5. - Filet: Presentation was decent, but the meat quality was basically the worst you could get for filet. The meat was not tender at all and really overcooked. Also not a fan of the wasabi sauce they used---it was really strong and drowned out any meat/bbq sauce flavor. 2/5. - Green tea mochi dessert: Rice flour was not fresh, and insides were average. 3/5.  Really disappointing meal for me, and with better balance of flavors and higher quality ingredients, this restaurant could improve by a bunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green tea mochi
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Filet
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yakisoba

zB2kwMXc873-5WPgH9NZgQ.text: This was a very unique Japanese restaurant. Service was great and we sat in front of the kitchen so we could watch. They offer many different options for sake and provided recommendations based on our tastes. This is a great spot to eat something different and break up the monotony.

DBthiYyIuTS3yrYYWEsV8g.text: You know your at the right Japanese spot when the only other two tables there are Japanese with thick accents. That, to me, says 'you have chosen correctly.'  Great ramen bowl, and tasted the pork and rice bowl as well. Everything was solid.   Plan on making it back for dinner soon...tbc

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork Ramen - A MUST HAVE

jGXEMqCy7SJy5WabvatwSA.text: I went here with a friend for lunch. We were very excited to find that there is a okonomiyaki place in Pittsburgh.   Unfortunately, our experiment failed. Big time.  I will tell any one that this place is not authentic AT ALL if you are expecting so. I could just sense that the atmosphere is nothing like Japanese--not even close-- the moment I stepped into the restaurant.   Food was pretty bad. Not horrible that I couldn't eat but bad that I would rather go to a different place.  We've had takoyaki and okonomiyaki. Takoyaki was crap. Okonomiyaki tasted like somewhat raw egg (bad), raw flour (bad), and cabbage. They did not blend in my mouth.  I'm giving 2 stars because the service was quite alright.

YlMKcs3xGzZVTjnfRsybqA.text: Try the Okonomiyaki!  I had the vegetarian option - very tasty, not too heavy.  The gyoza and calimari appetizers were also excellent.  If taking kids to this restaurant, order the Okonomiyaki - you will not regret it.  Hint: it moves.

zDSNfY47AgKMez1_9ZsTVQ.text: We've been here 5 times so far (including lunch and dinner) and have ordered a variety of dishes. They were all delicious. As a native Japanese, I found the dishes to taste of home and represented southern comfort Japanese food well. We enjoyed the okonomiyaki with pork, hiroshimayaki with pork, BBQ eggplant, shrimp avocado (which tastes more like American hibachi but was still one of the best tasting dishes), yaki onigiri with salmon, yakiudon, shoyu ramen, gyoza (which has a very delicate taste for a fried dumpling!) and good ol' yakisoba. If you are looking for some interesting Asian-fusion experience, this is not for you. If you are seeking authentic Japanese food, I highly recommend Teppanyaki Kyoto! The cost is well worth it if you're feeling nostalgic for Japan.

AS-HMoc259LMnO6kTIZYQA.text: If you're looking for Japanese that doesn't involve sushi in comes Teppanyaki Kyoto. Get their edamame with butter! Such a different spin. I've also had the Takoyaki, shrimp avocado, salmon Teppanyaki, yaki soba, okonomiyaki, hiroshimayaki and mochi ice cream - I've basically listed the entire menu! Everything is delicious and is affordable. Never thought that I'd see a restaurant like this available in Pittsburgh but am glad I stumbled upon it and tried it!

GdrlAGrhdG7VRR6gZm2Pww.text: I've been here twice and the value is great for the quality and portion size of the food you get. The saba no shioyaki appetizer is a huge portion and is delicious. The hiroshimayaki, which I've had twice, is also great. The atmosphere is cozy and beautiful, and the staff are kind and attentive. I love this place.

AGAk86C7oSBmAncB5wkQnA.text: I was in Japan for two months almost 9 years ago and haven't had Okonomiyaki since leaving. Their version was everything I remember loving and more! They didn't try to make it fancy. They didn't try to make it "fusion". They didn't dumb it down. Don't be scared by the mayo. This is okonomiyaki done right.   Also had a shrimp & avocado appetizer, which was incredible. The shrimp were done perfectly, juicy inside with a slight bite to the skin, and I had no idea that avocado could taste so good.

7cMauxpOAJHbyNsFq8KCOw.text: Very authentic okonomiyaki in a relaxed setting.  By far the best I've had outside of Japan.  The service was excellent and the whole experience felt like I'd been transported back to my days in Japan.  The seats at the counter offer a great view of the action in the kitchen.  The food itself was fantastic.  Authentic, filling and not at all expensive.  I highly recommend the octopus balls (they're better than they sound!), the miso soup, edamame and any one of their okonomiyakis.  Kevin, the chef/owner, spent some time chatting with us after our meal.  He has a great story - see if you can get him to tell it to you.  I wish they would do a ramen night... Everything there is delightfully authentic and delicious!

EUSrZwu04c3zuWKn_Dz6sg.text: Have now been here 4 times.  This is THE place for Japanese street food.  Everything is prepared and cooked to order and the open kitchen works like a well oiled machine.  On my last visit we closed the place and the chef was WONDERFUL and kept the kitchen open late for an bunch of hungry late night diners.

LjcPH1taSBzhKutrU5ZyZQ.text: This is one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh simply because they serve AUTHENTIC Japanese food.  The ambiance feels like a restaurant in Japan and the food is oishii (delicious).  Service can be a bit slow at times but it's worth it.  I never understood why so many people rave about Nakama on the Southside..if you want REAL Japanese food, go to Teppanyaki Kyoto!

E8oDl63TCtaUuhw2r0u9kQ.text: 2 stars for atmosphere only. We went for lunch, servings were beyond offensive.  I ordered avocados with shrimp.  1 avocado cubed with 4 small shrimp $10.  Disk on salad not with it...asked waitress question, she couldn't answer on small lunch menu.

S6OfTrWD8_YNrC5Czq5pLA.text: Very friendly chef and decent Japanese food ... Even better than some places in Japan when I was there!  The wait is long but it's definitely worth it!  Location is in the quiet neighborhood so the parking was quite easy.  Strongly recommend it!

IzPZ58G8Upvb6S2BekSCew.text: I went the last week with my husband because we wanted to know how it was and it was great! good food and nice place. totally recomended it!

Wvt2xwu1YUiJ4xOx5hcWTA.text: I had very high expectations for this restaurant since it served teppanyaki and okonomiyaki. I got the takoyaki and the Osaka Mix (shrimp, squid, and pork) for okonomiyaki. The octopus in the takoyaki and squid in the okonomiyaki were cooked to the point where they were rubbery and hard to eat. My friend got the teppanyaki with shrimp and I sampled her dish. The shrimp seemed like it had been pre-cooked and then added when the teppanyaki was being made. On top of that, we had to wait for a long time to get seated even though the waitress kept on saying that we would be seated in ten-fifteen minutes.

c7jJ_DQUrINo-v5WDflVHw.text: Probably my favourite Japanese restaurant ever. I've been here several times and the food is always great, the interior nice and clean, good service and all that. They don't have sushi, but they have lots of other things that I've been hard-pressed to find elsewhere, like okonomiyaki (they're known for it), daigaku imo, amezake, and so forth. They have a seasonal menu that changes... seasonally, and it's always worth a look. They also have stuff you can find more easily at other Japanese restaurants like yakisoba, ramen, gyuudon if you want something more familiar (that isn't sushi) but still better than average.

qFPV58giA0uQGVRVTCWeWg.text: I was debating between a 3 star and a 4 star because the food was good but not great. But I do like the idea of an open kitchen so 4 star it is. The food portion is on the smaller side. I've been there a bunch of times with friends, this is a place that I wouldn't go by myself because there are better Japanese restaurant choices imo. But I wouldn't mind going there once in a while with friends because after all, it is who we are dining with that matters and this place does have that cozy atmosphere which is perfect for hanging out with friends.

p1uS540rvyqafveRwgv3WQ.text: I'm not very adventurous so I chose not to try the okonomiyaki. I had the chicken meatballs as an appetizer and spicy Japanese udon noodles. Both were amazing! The three other people in my party did try the okonomiyaki and really enjoyed it. I tasted theirs and it did taste really good. This place is extremely authentic and everything we had was delicious. I also had the strawberry mousse for dessert, which was very good. My friend also tried the Japanese bacon mochi appetizer and green team mochi for dessert. I highly recommend you give it a try. We need more authentic local restaurants in Pittsburgh.

-MI9nHekJgBXVAl575nOhQ.text: We went for my birthday luncheon.  The food was simply delicious.    We had a number of appetizers.  The portions are small.  One appetizer is really meant for one, (or two if you are intimate with someone.)  The seaweed salad was crunchy and yummy.  The bacon wrapped mochi cake was a bit of savory lusciousness.  I guess everything is better with bacon!  My friend K. got the miso which was homemade, fresh and cleansing.  The pork dish I got as an entree was less memorable than the appetizers, but the vegetable entree that my friend R. ordered looked so great and healthy, I couldn't help but steal a few bites.  Wonderful!  I had only 2 caveats.  First, the waitress would not let us sit at a table, only at the front counter.  It was lovely to talk to our chefs, but difficult to talk to one another.  I think it was just a cultural misunderstanding.  I am sure the best seats are at the counter in Japan.  The other caveat, it is not a cheap, however, for real Japanese faire, with fresh ingredients, tastefully made, it's worth a little extra.    For a lunch that is flavorful, memorable and you can walk away from feeling healthier than when you got there, you cannot go wrong frequenting this little gem.

Q5xfDuWnKpUr4bEQAFoaVg.text: I normally think of Japanese food as being very light.  I can eat sushi all day without feeling weighted down.  When you first step in and see chefs dicing cucumbers to lightly stirfry you assume you're in for the same experience, but after my dish I felt like I had eaten a bowling ball.  (I normally have a pretty cast iron stomach, so take heed)  This was my first teppanyaki experience, so I can't compare it to other places, but while the food was tasty it was absolutely SOAKED in mayonnaise, it felt like a mayonnaise casserole.  Me and my family all got different styles of their signature teppanyaki dishes but they are wall the same mayo bathes.  Despite that, I'm still going to give them 4 stars, because I believe my problem is actually with teppanyaki, not a criticism of their preparation of it.  (No one could justifiable criticize a restaurants fried chicken for being a bit heavy)  The appetizers  (especially the bacon wrapped mochi) were all delicious and much lighter, so when I go back I'm going to stick to those instead!

fipA8mz14ZpiXSbRjeYSpg.text: This place is amazing. Very unique food and atmosphere. I love their fried avocado appetizer and mochi ice cream. My boyfriend and I went here once when we were vising from Ohio, and can't wait to come back! You may want to avoid going during their busiest hours, as seating is somewhat limited.

fjH-IYsPF6lPC6J3EYgS5Q.text: Love the ramen here during the freezing snowy days!

UezgO7EjSlLECuwbIOoVCA.text: Authentic Japanese environment and food. Really cool little place that I love! Got their speciality and it was amazing. Very reasonably priced too. Can't wait to go back all the time.

RIp8tnjNKPhVxGyzwrfo4g.text: Teppanyaki Kyoto is as close to Japan as I will ever come. Settled in a beautiful street in Highland Park, it offers humble preparations that will blow your mind. I've learned to hardly look at the menu and put our trust in the waiting staff who will treat you like family. Everything they recommend they do so with extreme pride and results which live up to the hype. I first came here on a quiet evening and was shocked at just how delicious and fresh everything was. Next, my husband and I brought a good friend of ours who had just returned from a semester abroad in Japan - she vouched for the authenticity but said that even she would've been hard-pressed to find something this good on the streets of Tokyo. Then, we came to celebrate the return of our brother from being stationed in South Korea in the military. We toasted with the Sake given to the Prime Minister of Japan as recommended by our favorite waiter, Steve. The atmosphere is unmistakable and the memories made here unforgettable. For us, this restaurant is everything that Pittsburgh is; proud, unique and unarguably wonderful. Try the eel - try the Korokke - try anything Steve recommends. You'll feel like your apart of their family and will soon be making plans for who you'll bring with you on your next stop in.

Br81l9iJmXWIvBcP32IySw.text: This is my new favorite restaurant!  My husband and I only had a small sampling of the menu (okonomiyaki, takoyaki, gyoza, and sake), but it was all fantastically delicious.  The okonomiyaki was the tastiest thing I've ever had!  All the food was cooked perfectly and the restaurant itself had such a pleasant, authentic vibe.  Can't wait to go back!

Lki3z59KNY2w62MDTVlHyw.text: How on EARTH had I never been to or even heard of this place! We recently visited based on the recommendation of a friend who had lived in Japan for awhile. She loved it, so we figured we would give it a shot. Service was very friendly and accommodating. Our small party had a vegetarian and they were more than happy to accommodate her with a Udon dish with vegetables and tofu. If you are a vegetarian, make sure to ask what they recommend as there are options that are not listed on the menu! Wine selection was acceptable, good quality wines and a good price point. Not a ton of a selection, but you don't really need it. I believe there were 3-4 different Sakes available as well as a few types of beer. What more do you really need? For appetizers we ordered the Gyoza, the calamari, the chicken meatballs, the scallops, and the potato cakes with vegetables. The potato cakes were a seasonal special and were fantastic. The sauce that was served with them was a perfect accompaniment! I would highly recommend them! The gyoza was also fantastic and our friend really enjoyed her scallops. I did not try the calamari but I heard it was wonderful as well. And I adored the chicken meatballs. They knocked it out of the park with the appetizers for sure.  For our meals, we were unsure about the hiroshimayaki, but don't be! It was AMAZING. My husband ordered his with beef and I am telling you I about climbed the table to eat nearly half of his meal. Wonderful stuff and so different. I had previously tried okonomiyaki from the food truck Fukuda and found it to be cloyingly rich. I just did not enjoy it, not even a little bit. But Teppanyaki Kyoto's hiroshimayaki is what Fukuda's okonomiyaki dreams of becoming one day. Perfectly balanced, and delicious. Yes the two dishes are inherently different, as the okonomiyaki doesn't have the egg or the noodles, but the flavors are essentially the same and Teppanyaki Kyoto knows better than to over power the flavors with too much mayonnaise. One of our friends also tried the green tea cheesecake and said it was also wonderful. All in all, a fantastic evening out with wonderful service and food. I would love to return! They also had a very nice selection of lunch specials! This is not a heavily trafficked area of Highland Park, but my Pittsburgh Zoo friends should definitely give this place a try!

sNqCw1UQNJv7bdPsFaw-Ww.text: Each dish looks delicate. I had 10 dishes, which only cost less than $90. I recommend the duck breast, eel with rice.

Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

rCWTUsW1HCaHwbfjxz57cw.text: The best takoyaki I've ever tasted in Pittsburgh!

N97hyqCnxKkeX1C3Uo6rDg.text: Get the hiroshimayaki or the okonomiyaki. They are very similar, except that the hiroshimayaki has a layer of yakisoba noodles on top. This is the dish that you cannot find elsewhere in Pittsburgh and, in my opinion, it alone is worth coming to the restaurant for. Since it takes 25 minutes to prepare -- order it early. Come with a group of people (maybe 4-5 in total) to get tatami seating for the best experience. As with all Asian fare, best way to enjoy your food is to order various dishes and share.   Since the portions are quite small, you'll need to order quite a few dishes or order a bowl of rice to really feel full (costs extra). I went with a friend and we got: hiyayako (silken tofu), grilled yellowtail, grilled hokke (mackerel), beef hiroshimayaki, and three servings orders of green tea ice cream for dessert. This was just enough to fill the two of us up and the total came out to about $54 in total. I found the grilled hokke to be too dry, salty, and lacking in flavor. Would not order it again.   This place gets four stars for serving delicious food that is difficult to find elsewhere in Pittsburgh, although I do wish that they offered a college special so that I could come here more often!

Mo8EMpvzE6LRaPjpxN3s7g.text: Teppanyaki Kyoto is the best Japanese comfort food in the city. My husband and I had just come back from our honeymoon to Japan and were jonesing for some takoyaki and this might be the only place in the city to get some. We decided to take my parents with us this time and they loved it. We did keep comparing it to what we had had two months prior in Japan and it comes pretty darn close! EVeryone throughly enjoyed their meal and you will to! I suggest the takoyaki and Okonomiyaki. YUM.

ipI03dWsJvpoKJ3A43WdQw.text: Japanese comfort food.   Messy, greasy, and salty, just as I expect street food to be. But you don't get street food prices here... I think everything costs a few dollars more than I think is reasonable for the type of food that it is, but in return, you dine in a pretty sleek-looking place. Very clean, modern, minimalist decor.   The servers are always polite and welcoming, but the food service (especially if you order things from the grill) ends up taking awhile. Be prepared to be patient for your food.   I'd say it's definitely worth a try, especially if you're interested in trying Japanese comfort food. Just know it's not going to blow your socks off.

HC_ByArnbMuIbzcYKnUhSg.text: Japanese food executed well. Few and far between in this city. The pancake thing I will remember for years. I wish it were cheaper or further from my house so I would stop going there. Service is always good and again that pancake thing.

WTggRzuK0CYWEZRlRdi56w.text: Came here on a whim earlier this month.  Bacon wrapped mochi was good, not great. There was a glaze (tasted alcoholic) that I thought was a little too strong. My boyfriend was not a fan of the mochi at all - he thought it was too chewy.  Yakisoba noodles w/ chicken were okay.  Okonomiyaki (we got it w/ beef and noodles) was yummy but very, very salty.  Not sure if I would come back, I think it will depend on their seasonal menus.

9BPKnKznXQgCCHBC_UvElg.text: Again, I've become a willing victim to a restaurant on Bryant Street (walking distance from my house) :/  I had a bad day and my friend was gracious enough to help me wallow in misery.  Well when we stumbled on this place, my frown turned upside down!  It was rather late when we got there and I realized it was Teppanyaki Kyoto- a place I've wanted to try since hearing about their Okonomiyaki.  Sadly, we didn't have time for the 25 minute wait for the epic dish.  Since I'll DEFINITELY be back- no worries.  When I saw the group of Japanese business men laughing and enjoying their meals, I knew we were in the right place.  My dining partner had just started a cleanse, so he was only able to have a salad, a chicken breast and vegetables, but the restaurant graciously accommodated.  I thoroughly enjoyed my Yaki-Soba- everything was seasoned to PERFECTION and way cheaper than expected!  Really, I love this place and I'm sure I'll be back again and again and again.

HJ236n8GYAu6II-XY25L1Q.text: I'm really torn, because I'd like a business like this to exist on Bryant and do well, but aside from the atmosphere and friendly service, I'm not really sure what the fascination is. Maybe if the pricing was lower... (maybe I'd find one or two staples that tasted OK) everything comes out of a pre-packaged frozen bag and cooked straight from frozen state. It doesn't seem like there's much authentic about it, maybe this is how it's done in other restaurants, but don't do it right in front of me. I feel like even if we couldn't see how they make the food, we would still think something was weird, and just not understand why everything tastes weird.   Noodles - again out of little pre-packaged bags - very gummy. Come on... noodles! How to you mess up noodles?  Calamari - I think... I really think... pig (you know). It just tasted really weird - very tough and extremely chewy...   We had a hard time finishing any of our food. Salt. Salt, salt.

mcrLtjgF3tpgmtI18wVwjQ.text: So far my favorite Japanese restaurant in Pitts.

photos.caption: Photo of Teppanyaki Kyoto - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pancake!

SapYLiWHnta8IWpczEu2sg.text: I am so excited that Pittsburgh has a Japanese comfort food restaurant. My husband and I went for the second time last night, and on either side of us were full blown Japanese conversations. So many Asians! So, you know this is legit.  We've tried a number of the small plates and the okonomiyaki. Everything is good. Don't come here looking for sushi - they don't have it. But the pancakes... oh, cabbagey goodness. They are difficult to describe... not exactly pancakes (because they are savory) and not pizza either, because the ingredients are cooked into the pancake itself. Perhaps consider adding a new term to your vocab: okonomiyaki!  Definitely sit at the counter if you can.

_5w2B3q1VJUuAm_4a3Yrcg.text: This is my first yelp review in Pittsburgh since I've been living in this town for over a year, and there's a reason this place inspired me to. As a San Francisco Bay Area native where there's never a shortage of foodie places, I've been quite critical on Pittsburgh. However! There are a definitely a bunch of stand outs (and my list is growing!) and this is one of them.   The okonomiyaki was AMAZING. Other okonomiyakis that have graced my tummy in SF Japantown pale in comparison to this one- True story. I sat at the counter and couldn't help but respect the craft that they commanded to create this stuff.   The bacon wrapped mochi was just as yummy...they slow seared the mochi on all sides, and then did it all over again after they wrapped it in bacon.  I love bacon though so I might be biased on this one.  I went on a Wednesday night with my roomie and everyone was so friendly and attentive. I would definitely recommend this place and will be coming back and plan on telling all my friends about it and dragging all my out of town visitors here. Thanks for the yummy food!

1HNrnVTSSEgRjVZ4kiuhJA.text: After wanting to go there for a long time, I finally went there a couple of months back. This isn't your typical Japanese sushi place, so be warned.  the Okonomyaki was really good, nothing like what I had tasted before and was great. The appetizers were pretty darn good as well. The service was a bit meh.  We had no idea what things were supposed to look like so we ended up getting a small plate that someone else had ordered so we just ate it. We explained our qualm to the waiter and were still charged for it at the end.  Other than that, I do want to go back again and try other things on the menu.  It is a tad bit expensive too, so do go knowing that.

pS-y56neKyoBFPxoHxo1Ng.text: This place is SO good, best Japaneese in Pittsburgh.  Go in and get a smattering of appitizers, the octopus balls are fantastic and the gyoza is mandatory.  Then to the pancake, as everyone is mentioning, they dance, they're delicious, etc.  I strongly recommend the one with the noodles.  And sit at the counter if you can, it's worth watching how they make the stuff up.

gR1JN6bz5XklwFbEJvqI8A.text: Delicious yaki udon. Squid always worries me that it will be over cooked but it was cooked perfectly. Definitely coming back for dinner because I want to try the "pancake".

ha8mne2iKIUAj0PgPCZ9CA.text: Teppanyaki Kyoto is my happy place. The takoyaki balls, okonomiyaki, and unagi don are my favorites. This place is authentic, delicious, and has a great atmosphere. I'm looking forward to visiting again soon for my birthday!
